comments:
Error when modifying/saving a JUnit test suite.

Using TPTP 4.0 (200507141319 build), opening the test-
results\platform\org.eclipse.hyades.use.cases\junit\Profiling_and_Logging\Java_P
rofiler.testsuite JUnit test suite from the TPTP test resource module in TPTP's 
CVS repository, and modifying (e.g. add a new test case) the test suite causing 
the enclosed error when saving:

!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.resources 4 372 2005-07-19 09:34:10.114
!MESSAGE Resource /org.eclipse.hyades.use.cases is not open.

After investigating with Joe, this defect is only caused when extracting the 
test-results CVS module and attempting to modify the test-
results\platform\org.eclipse.hyades.use.cases\junit\Profiling_and_Logging\Java_P
rofiler.testsuite JUnit test suite.  When extracting the 
org.eclipse.hyades.use.cases plug-in project from CVS and attempting to modify 
the org.eclipse.hyades.use.cases\junit\Profiling_and_Logging\Java_P
rofiler.testsuite JUnit test suite, the problem does not exist.  The issue is 
with the automatic code generation upon saving the test suite since the path to 
the source folder is project relative.  Containing plug-in and Java projects in 
subdirectories within the Eclipse workspace is not supported.

Please retarget this defect for 4.1 to address the usability of error condition 
(i.e. handling the error condition and a more user friendly error message).

Julien, do you have time to take a look at this for 4.1, and if not, can you 
recommend a delegate?

Fixed.
The following changes were applied:
- The Test Suite editor allows to view/edit the source folder where the code is
generated
- When saving the test suite, if the source folder does not exist, the code is
not generated and the following message is displayed: "The source folder: <src>
does not exist in the workspace. The code for this test cannot be generated
until you specify an existing source folder." The user may create/import/check
out the missing project, or adjust the project/source folder information in the
editor, then save the test suite again.
- The above behavior also applies when the source project is closed, and when
the package or class names are invalid.

Verified in TPTP_v4_1_0_200510140100 on Oct. 17, 2005.  However, the save 
operation continues breaking the synchronization between the test suite and 
generated code when 'Implement Test Behaviour as Code'.

Paul, can you specify what you mean with "continues breaking the 
synchronization between the test suite and generated code" (actions/expected 
behavior/observed behavior). I didn't have a chance to try the build you're 
reffering to yet, but I'm not aware of synchronizations problems in previous 
builds.

(In reply to comment #6)

The test suite is saved with newly added test cases despite not having added 
the test cases to the generated Java class.

While I was looking at the projet o.e.h.use.cases, I noticed that the project is
missing the builder org.eclipse.hyades.test.tools.core.java.junit.builder, which
is required for the code synchronization to work (so the a modification to the
java file is propagated to the model). I have modified the code updater so it
ensures that, any time you save a test suite, this builder is added to the
project. This should be useful when working with projects that were created with
a release < 4.0. The builder was added only when creating a new TPTP JUnit test,
and when importing a JUnit test to TPTP.
If you intent to make structural modifications (add, remove or rename methods)
to a JUnit test source code, please make sure that this builder is listed in the
project's builders (in .project file), otherwise you're likely to run into problems.

The CVS history of Java_Profiler.java tells me that all method names have been
converted to full lower-case recently. This causes the model to not recognize
these methods (the model is still using mixed-case method names), so it
re-creates them upon model save. I recommend that you the same tip as in bug
109668 comment 10, to resynchronize the model with the code.

Verified in TPTP_v4_1_0_200510220100.

This workaround threw the following exception so I re-imported all of the 
affect test suites as well as updated the 
org.eclipse.hyades.tests\AllJUnitTests.testsuite test suite under this defect:
